channel.title: World & Nation
channel.description: Nation and World articles from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Senate rejects impeachment of Homeland Security Secretary Mayorkas
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, a Cuban immigrant who grew up in California, is the first U.S. Cabinet official impeached in nearly 150 years.
item.content:encoded: Alejandro N. Mayorkas, a Cuban immigrant who grew up in California, is the first U.S. Cabinet official impeached in nearly 150 years.

item.title: Abortion ban has supercharged Arizona politics. What will GOP legislators do?
item.dc:creator: Noah Bierman
item.description: As abortion politics and policy clash in Arizona and threaten to sway the swing state, GOP lawmakers scramble to address the issue amid fallout from a ruling reviving an 1864 ban.
item.content:encoded: As abortion politics and policy clash in Arizona and threaten to sway the swing state, GOP lawmakers scramble to address the issue amid fallout from a ruling reviving an 1864 ban.

media:content.media:title: 1436808-na-abortion-rally-phoenix-3-gmf.jpg
media:content.media:description: PHOENIX, AZ - APRIL 16, 2024: Arizona residents rally for abortion rights on a street corner Tuesday on the heels of the Arizona's Supreme Court decision enacting an 1864 law banning abortion on April 16, 2024 in Phoenix, Arizona.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: This trans author toured red-state libraries. What she found might surprise you
item.dc:creator: Diana Goetsch
item.description: Diana Goetsch spent months visiting red-state libraries to do presentations on the freedom to read. Would she be recognized, or clocked as transgender?
item.content:encoded: Diana Goetsch spent months visiting red-state libraries to do presentations on the freedom to read. Would she be recognized, or clocked as transgender?

item.title: Supreme Court casts doubt on obstruction charges against hundreds of Jan. 6 rioters
item.dc:creator: David G. Savage
item.description: Supreme Court conservatives questioned whether the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act can be used to prosecute those who attacked the U.S. Capitol in 2021.
item.content:encoded: Supreme Court conservatives questioned whether the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act can be used to prosecute those who attacked the U.S. Capitol in 2021.

item.title: Goldberg: For Israel and Ukraine alike, U.S. support is proving unreliable and inadequate
item.dc:creator: Jonah Goldberg
item.description: Biden urged Benjamin Netanyahu to refrain from retaliation against Iran even though its attack appeared to defy the president's own warning after Oct. 7.
item.content:encoded: Biden urged Benjamin Netanyahu to refrain from retaliation against Iran even though its attack appeared to defy the president's own warning after Oct. 7.

item.title: Damage found inside Glen Canyon Dam increases water risks on the Colorado River
item.dc:creator: Ian James
item.description: Newly discovered damage in Glen Canyon Dam would require releasing less water at low reservoir levels — a problem that increases water risks in the Southwest.
item.content:encoded: Newly discovered damage in Glen Canyon Dam would require releasing less water at low reservoir levels — a problem that increases water risks in the Southwest.

item.title: The abortion debate is giving Kamala Harris a moment. But voters still aren't sold
item.dc:creator: Noah Bierman
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris has failed to win over a majority of voters or convince them that she is ready to step in if Biden, the oldest president in history, falters.
item.content:encoded: Vice President Kamala Harris has failed to win over a majority of voters or convince them that she is ready to step in if Biden, the oldest president in history, falters.

item.title: Column: Are Republicans who got pandemic debt relief hypocrites for complaining about student debt relief? Yes
item.dc:creator: Michael Hiltzik
item.description: Republicans criticizing Biden's student debt relief plan took millions of dollars in pandemic relief loans and never paid them back. But they say that's different.
item.content:encoded: Republicans criticizing Biden's student debt relief plan took millions of dollars in pandemic relief loans and never paid them back. But they say that's different.

item.title: Too expensive, too slow: NASA asks for help with JPL's Mars Sample Return mission
item.dc:creator: Corinne Purtill
item.description: NASA's administrator says the agency is committed to the mission to bring samples of Mars back to Earth -- but in less time and for less money. How it will pull that off remains to be seen.
item.content:encoded: NASA's administrator says the agency is committed to the mission to bring samples of Mars back to Earth -- but in less time and for less money. How it will pull that off remains to be seen.

media:content.media:title: PIA25738.png
media:content.media:description: These tubes hold samples of rock cores and regolith (broken rock and dust) collected by NASA's Perseverance rover for the Mars Sample Return campaign, which aims to bring Martian samples to Earth for closer study.

item.title: Litman: Trump's antics didn't stop his New York hush money trial. Here's why he'll keep them up
item.dc:creator: Harry Litman
item.description: The former president can be expected to stick to his political strategy despite its legal risks and Judge Juan M. Merchan's lack of patience for it.
item.content:encoded: The former president can be expected to stick to his political strategy despite its legal risks and Judge Juan M. Merchan's lack of patience for it.

item.title: Biden administration gives California $45 million to help recently arrived migrants
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: California is receiving a slightly larger share of a federal program earmarking $300 million nationwide for migrant-assistance programs.
item.content:encoded: California is receiving a slightly larger share of a federal program earmarking $300 million nationwide for migrant-assistance programs.

media:content.media:title: Migrants hoping to cross into the United States from Tijuana, Mexico, wait south of the border wall in anticipation of a change in immigration policy, Title 42.
media:content.media:description: U.S. border, United States-May 11, 2023-U.S. border patrol agents make contact with migrants hoping to cross into the United States from Tijuana, Mexico on May 11, 2023. Some migrants have been waiting a week in an area south of the second border wall in anticipation of a change in immigration policy, Title 42, which may allow them to apply for asylum. U.S. border patrol agents give out one bottle of water and one granola bar to each person. There are approximately 500 people in this one camp. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'Rust' armorer Hannah Gutierrez sentenced to 18 months in prison
item.dc:creator: Meg James
item.description: A New Mexico judge excoriated the 26-year-old Arizona woman, who loaded Alec Baldwin's gun with five dummy rounds and one lead bullet, which killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins in October 2021.
item.content:encoded: A New Mexico judge excoriated the 26-year-old Arizona woman, who loaded Alec Baldwin's gun with five dummy rounds and one lead bullet, which killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins in October 2021.

item.title: News Analysis: Can both sides declare victory in Iran-Israel clash?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Wilkinson, Nabih Bulos
item.description: Can U.S. officials and other world leaders persuade Israel and Iran to avoid dragging the Middle East into a wider war?
item.content:encoded: Can U.S. officials and other world leaders persuade Israel and Iran to avoid dragging the Middle East into a wider war?

item.title: Q&A: Yes, Trump could be elected president as a convicted felon
item.dc:creator: David G. Savage
item.description: Donald Trump faces multiple criminal charges, but a conviction would not legally prevent him from serving as president — in theory, even from jail.
item.content:encoded: Donald Trump faces multiple criminal charges, but a conviction would not legally prevent him from serving as president — in theory, even from jail.

item.title: 'Miracle' weight-loss drugs could have reduced health disparities. Instead they got worse
item.dc:creator: Karen Kaplan
item.description: Ozempic and other drugs raised the possibility of reversing the country's obesity crisis. Doctors are frustrated that they've made health disparities worse.
item.content:encoded: Ozempic and other drugs raised the possibility of reversing the country's obesity crisis. Doctors are frustrated that they've made health disparities worse.

item.title: Column: Joe Biden's empathy was his superpower in 2020. Can he find it again in 2024?
item.dc:creator: Doyle McManus
item.description: President Biden, in an election battle with Trump, touts the economy. Democratic strategists say the message is missing Biden's big strength: empathy.
item.content:encoded: President Biden, in an election battle with Trump, touts the economy. Democratic strategists say the message is missing Biden's big strength: empathy.

item.title: Trump's trial is about more than sex and money. It's about what presidents 'can get away with'
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Fleishman
item.description: Donald Trump's hush money trial is about more than Stormy Daniels and sex. It "will shape not just what future presidents will do but whether or not they'll get away with it."
item.content:encoded: Donald Trump's hush money trial is about more than Stormy Daniels and sex. It "will shape not just what future presidents will do but whether or not they'll get away with it."

item.title: 'Nobody saw this coming'; California dairies scramble to guard herds against bird flu
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: As the avian flu continues to threaten poultry farms and wildlife, are factory farms a sitting duck?
item.content:encoded: As the avian flu continues to threaten poultry farms and wildlife, are factory farms a sitting duck?

media:content.media:title: 921431-na-us-calif-biofuels-bakersfield-17-brv.jpg
media:content.media:description: Bakersfield, CA - March 01: Cows wait to enter the milk barn for milking at a Kern County dairy Tuesday, March 1, 2022 in Bakersfield, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Iran launches airstrikes toward Israel in retaliatory move, boosting chance of wider conflict
item.dc:creator: Tracy Wilkinson
item.description: Iran launched a drone and missile attack on Israel in a significant escalation of regional conflict amid the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza. Israel says it intercepted the 'vasty majority.'
item.content:encoded: Iran launched a drone and missile attack on Israel in a significant escalation of regional conflict amid the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza. Israel says it intercepted the 'vasty majority.'

item.title: Trump's untruths pile up. Biden gets facts wrong too. Do voters care?
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Trump said he talked to a crime victim's family. Her sister denied it. And the fact-checkers called out the former president, again.
item.content:encoded: Trump said he talked to a crime victim's family. Her sister denied it. And the fact-checkers called out the former president, again.

item.title: U.S. bracing for potential Iranian response to attack attributed to Israel
item.dc:creator: Tracy Wilkinson
item.description: U.S. officials say Iran appears to be lining up a series of potential retaliations against Israel.
item.content:encoded: U.S. officials say Iran appears to be lining up a series of potential retaliations against Israel.

item.title: Builders may fight 'impact fees' that fund municipal projects in California, Supreme Court rules
item.dc:creator: David G. Savage
item.description: The Supreme Court says home builders in California may challenge the fees commonly imposed by cities and counties to pay for new infrastructure.
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court says home builders in California may challenge the fees commonly imposed by cities and counties to pay for new infrastructure.

item.title: Opinion: In Utah, the Capitol really is the people's house
item.dc:creator: Stephen Trimble
item.description: Every day, parachutists, protesters, presidents and posers show up on the front lawn, and at the front door of Utah state government.
item.content:encoded: Every day, parachutists, protesters, presidents and posers show up on the front lawn, and at the front door of Utah state government.

item.title: Ukrainians contemplate the once unthinkable: Losing the war with Russia
item.dc:creator: Laura King
item.description: Could Ukraine lose the war? Once nearly taboo, the question hovers in Kyiv, but Ukrainians believe they must fight for their lives against Putin's troops.
item.content:encoded: Could Ukraine lose the war? Once nearly taboo, the question hovers in Kyiv, but Ukrainians believe they must fight for their lives against Putin's troops.

item.title: Column: Presidential foundation was too scared to honor Liz Cheney, so he quit in disgust
item.dc:creator: Mark Z. Barabak
item.description: David Hume Kennerly quit the Gerald Ford Foundation board when the group refused to honor Liz Cheney because, Kennerly says, it's afraid of Donald Trump.
item.content:encoded: David Hume Kennerly quit the Gerald Ford Foundation board when the group refused to honor Liz Cheney because, Kennerly says, it's afraid of Donald Trump.

item.title: Why feds say Shohei Ohtani is a 'victim': Interpreter allegedly paid gambling debts pretending to be Dodger
item.dc:creator: Steve Henson
item.description: Federal authorities said evidence supports Dodger Shohei Ohtani's claims he was unaware of alleged illegal gambling by his interpreter and a victim of bank fraud. He can play ball.
item.content:encoded: Federal authorities said evidence supports Dodger Shohei Ohtani's claims he was unaware of alleged illegal gambling by his interpreter and a victim of bank fraud. He can play ball.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 28: Los Angeles Dodgers designated hitter Shohei Ohtani (17) looks back from first base during the fifth inning against the St. Louis Cardinals in Dodgers Stadium on Thursday, March 28, 2024 in Los Angeles, CA. (Wally Skalij / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: TSA found more than 1,500 firearms on airline passengers in first 3 months of 2024
item.dc:creator: Nathan Solis
item.description: A majority of the guns found were loaded, according to the TSA.
item.content:encoded: A majority of the guns found were loaded, according to the TSA.

media:content.media:title: 1396751-me-0110-tsa-lax-011-ik.jpg
media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JANUARY 10: LAWA Police Chief Cecil Rhambo, left, and TSA supervisor Jorge Pineda display the items confiscated during TSA screening, at press conference held at Los Angeles International Airport on Wednesday, Jan. 10, 2024 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dianne Feinstein made history. Now she could get honored with a post office?
item.dc:creator: Sarah D. Wire
item.description: The proposal to name a San Francisco post office after the late Sen. Dianne Feinstein struck some as unbefitting the gravitas of her half-century career in politics.
item.content:encoded: The proposal to name a San Francisco post office after the late Sen. Dianne Feinstein struck some as unbefitting the gravitas of her half-century career in politics.

media:content.media:title: Dianne Feinstein
media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE CA OCTOBER 11, 2017 --- Sen.Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) speaks at a lunch hosted by the Greater Riverside Chambers of Commerce convention Center, Riverside. Feinstein announced that she would seek a sixth term. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coastal salmon fishing banned for a second year amid steep population declines
item.dc:creator: Ian James
item.description: Officials have decided to ban salmon fishing on the California coast for a second year. Salmon populations have dropped after the state's last drought.
item.content:encoded: Officials have decided to ban salmon fishing on the California coast for a second year. Salmon populations have dropped after the state's last drought.

item.title: O.J. Simpson, whose murder trial riveted and divided the world, dies at 76
item.dc:creator: Elaine Woo
item.description: O.J. Simpson, whose rise and fall from American football hero to murder suspect to prison inmate fueled a public drama that obsessed the nation, has died.
item.content:encoded: O.J. Simpson, whose rise and fall from American football hero to murder suspect to prison inmate fueled a public drama that obsessed the nation, has died.

item.title: Column: California's transgender sanctuary law survives a challenge as judge ridicules plaintiff's claims
item.dc:creator: Michael Hiltzik
item.description: California gives sanctuary to kids seeking gender-affirming care and their families. A judge has upheld the law against an attack by a right-wing church.
item.content:encoded: California gives sanctuary to kids seeking gender-affirming care and their families. A judge has upheld the law against an attack by a right-wing church.

item.title: Jordanians protest nightly against peace deal with Israel amid anger over Gaza war
item.dc:creator: Nabih Bulos
item.description: Outraged over the war in Gaza, protesters gather every night near the Israeli Embassy in Jordan's capital to demand an end to peace agreements with Israel.
item.content:encoded: Outraged over the war in Gaza, protesters gather every night near the Israeli Embassy in Jordan's capital to demand an end to peace agreements with Israel.

item.title: Calmes: Trump 1.0 made some world leaders laugh. Trump 2.0 terrifies them
item.dc:creator: Jackie Calmes
item.description: Donald Trump says the world disrespects Biden, but he's projecting his own deep unpopularity onto the president.
item.content:encoded: Donald Trump says the world disrespects Biden, but he's projecting his own deep unpopularity onto the president.

item.title: William Howell wrote Arizona's 1864 abortion ban. He modeled it on California's
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho, Scott Wilson
item.description: William Howell wrote the Arizona law banning abortions in 1864. On Tuesday, 160 years later, Arizona's Supreme Court reinstated the law.
item.content:encoded: William Howell wrote the Arizona law banning abortions in 1864. On Tuesday, 160 years later, Arizona's Supreme Court reinstated the law.

item.title: Impeached Homeland Security secretary navigates working with Republicans who want him out
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: It has been two months since Alejandro Mayorkas, a California native and the highest-ranking Latino in the federal government, was narrowly impeached.
item.content:encoded: It has been two months since Alejandro Mayorkas, a California native and the highest-ranking Latino in the federal government, was narrowly impeached.

item.title: Litman: Jack Smith's latest push to get Donald Trump's Jan. 6 trial moving before the election
item.dc:creator: Harry Litman
item.description: The special counsel urged the Supreme Court to let the case proceed as soon as possible rather than delaying it for theoretical questions about presidential immunity.
item.content:encoded: The special counsel urged the Supreme Court to let the case proceed as soon as possible rather than delaying it for theoretical questions about presidential immunity.

item.title: Why Biden is getting little credit for the economy, especially in California
item.dc:creator: Don Lee
item.description: In dealing with the economy, President Biden faces all-too-real consequences of higher inflation, and he's also battling human psychology.
item.content:encoded: In dealing with the economy, President Biden faces all-too-real consequences of higher inflation, and he's also battling human psychology.

item.title: Trump is going on trial in New York today. Here's what to expect
item.dc:creator: Sarah D. Wire
item.description: Trump faces the first of four criminal trials that will cut into his campaigning. He is accused of falsifying records to hide payments to a porn actor.
item.content:encoded: Trump faces the first of four criminal trials that will cut into his campaigning. He is accused of falsifying records to hide payments to a porn actor.

item.title: Column: Trump hoped to sidestep the abortion issue. Arizona's near-total ban shows why he can't
item.dc:creator: Mark Z. Barabak
item.description: Instead of deflecting, Trump's move places his political fate in the hands of judges and state lawmakers willing to go far beyond where most voters stand.
item.content:encoded: Instead of deflecting, Trump's move places his political fate in the hands of judges and state lawmakers willing to go far beyond where most voters stand.

item.title: Federal EPA limits toxic 'forever chemicals' in drinking water
item.dc:creator: Melody Petersen
item.description: The EPA has issued federal limits on dangerous "forever chemicals" in drinking water, which it says will save thousands of lives and prevent serious illnesses.
item.content:encoded: The EPA has issued federal limits on dangerous "forever chemicals" in drinking water, which it says will save thousands of lives and prevent serious illnesses.

media:content.media:title: 468667_la-na-pol-pfas-contamination-ca_446.jpg
media:content.media:description: ORANGE COUNTY, CA-OCTOBER 9, 2019: Enrique Flores Arteaga raises a water sample that is left with a concentrated testing element to check for PFAS compounds at the Orange County Water District on October 9, 2019 in Orange County, California. Officials will release new water quality results this week that will show widespread contamination of PFAS, a toxic chemical linked to cancer. (Photo By Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: And the heat keeps coming: Global temperature record broken for 10th month in a row in March
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: With an average surface temperature of 57.45 degrees, last month was warmer than any previous March on record, according to European climate officials.
item.content:encoded: With an average surface temperature of 57.45 degrees, last month was warmer than any previous March on record, according to European climate officials.

item.title: Arizona's ban on abortion sets up the swing state for an election 2024 showdown
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho, Seema Mehta
item.description: The Arizona Supreme Court's ruling Tuesday made abortions illegal, except when a mother's life is at risk. Attention quickly turned to the November election.
item.content:encoded: The Arizona Supreme Court's ruling Tuesday made abortions illegal, except when a mother's life is at risk. Attention quickly turned to the November election.

media:content.media:title: 1168879-me-arizonas-last-abortion-clinic-1-gmf.jpg
media:content.media:description: PHOENIX, AZ - AUGUST 1, 2022: On an early August morning, women are lined up outside Camelback Family Planning to try and get an appointment at the only surgical abortion clinic left in the entire state of Arizona on August 1, 2022 in Phoenix, Arizona.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The war in Gaza reshapes Ramadan into a somber ritual in Jerusalem's Old City
item.dc:creator: Marcus Yam, Tracy Wilkinson
item.description: As Ramadan fasting ends amid the Israel-Hamas war, Palestinian Muslims in Jerusalem's Old City are somber, skipping festivities in sympathy with Gazans' suffering.
item.content:encoded: As Ramadan fasting ends amid the Israel-Hamas war, Palestinian Muslims in Jerusalem's Old City are somber, skipping festivities in sympathy with Gazans' suffering.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0404-israelgazawar-mwy-93023.jpg
media:content.media:description: JERUSALEM, ISRAEL -- MARCH 22, 2024: Worshippers listen to a sermon about the suffering in Gaza during Dhuhr afternoon prayers in the Al-Aqsa mosque compound in Jerusalem, Israel, Friday, March 22, 2024. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Trump says leave abortion to the states. That's where it gets complicated
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Trump said abortion access should be decided by the states. But that has been more complicated than it sounds.
item.content:encoded: Trump said abortion access should be decided by the states. But that has been more complicated than it sounds.

item.title: An Oregon tribe's casino bid sparks furor over what land tribes can rightfully call home
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wiley
item.description: The Coquille tribe wants to build a casino on the California border. Pushback from nearby tribes raises a question: Who gets to determine a tribe's rightful homeland?
item.content:encoded: The Coquille tribe wants to build a casino on the California border. Pushback from nearby tribes raises a question: Who gets to determine a tribe's rightful homeland?

media:content.media:title: 1411694-me-casino-battle-norcal-12-brv.jpg
media:content.media:description: Yreka, CA - February 06: Northern California Karuk Tribal chairman Russell 'Buster' Attebery at the tribe's Rain Rock Casino, on Tuesday, Feb. 6, 2024 in Yreka, CA. There's a big battle brewing with the Coquille Indian Tribe's proposed Cedars at Bear Creek casino, with the Karuk tribe contending it will eat into their own revenues and once again put tribes in competition with one another (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Biden proposes new student-debt relief. Here's who would benefit
item.dc:creator: Jon Healey
item.description: After months of negotiations, the administration is proposing a rule to reduce the debts of millions of borrowers. But the plan will likely face legal challenges.
item.content:encoded: After months of negotiations, the administration is proposing a rule to reduce the debts of millions of borrowers. But the plan will likely face legal challenges.

item.title: L.A. Times Executive Editor Terry Tang solidifies leadership position
item.dc:creator: Meg James
item.description: Since being tapped as interim executive editor, Tang moved rapidly to reorganize the newsroom, form her own leadership team and put a heavier emphasis on traditional news gathering.
item.content:encoded: Since being tapped as interim executive editor, Tang moved rapidly to reorganize the newsroom, form her own leadership team and put a heavier emphasis on traditional news gathering.

item.title: Democrats book $27 million in ads in California congressional races
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: The ad buy includes more than $19 million in L.A., a media market where some hotly contested congressional races could determine control of the House.
item.content:encoded: The ad buy includes more than $19 million in L.A., a media market where some hotly contested congressional races could determine control of the House.

item.title: How an L.A. humanitarian group is using soccer to help children stuck at Mexico border
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: An L.A.-based nonprofit with support from Angel City FC is using soccer to help children stranded on the U.S.-Mexico border cope with waiting for asylum.
item.content:encoded: An L.A.-based nonprofit with support from Angel City FC is using soccer to help children stranded on the U.S.-Mexico border cope with waiting for asylum.

media:content.media:title: soccer11.jpg
media:content.media:description: Children play soccer at the Sidewalk School in Matamoros, Mexico.

item.title: Cost of work visas surges, upping the ante for multitude of California's small businesses
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo, Don Lee
item.description: Experts said the visa fee hikes could make a difference in some employers' efforts to recruit foreign workers.
item.content:encoded: Experts said the visa fee hikes could make a difference in some employers' efforts to recruit foreign workers.

media:content.media:title: 1432038-me-immigrant-worker-visa-fees-increase-06-ajs.jpg
media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - April 05: Ally Bolour, an immigration attorney, photographed at his Bolour/Carl Immigration Group office in Los Angeles Friday, April 5, 2024. Bolour's clients, many of them entertainment industry companies looking to hire foreign actors and other artists for film shoots, must pay more for filings in the wake of the U.S. government's sweeping visa fee increases that took effect on Monday. He says the extra visa expenses already have made some clients delay planned expansions to the U.S. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: It's not just RFK Jr.: Biden faces serious danger from third-party candidates
item.dc:creator: Doyle McManus
item.description: Biden isn't running only against Trump. An anti-vax Kennedy and other third-party candidates could draw enough Democratic defectors to swing the election.
item.content:encoded: Biden isn't running only against Trump. An anti-vax Kennedy and other third-party candidates could draw enough Democratic defectors to swing the election.

media:content.media:title: 1426446-me-0330-rfk-cesar-chavez-gem-001.jpg
media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 30, 2024 - - Independent Presidential Candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., against a mural of images of him as a young man, hosts Cesar Chavez Day to celebrate the life and legacy of Cesar Chavez at the iconic Old Ticket Concourse at Union Station in Los Angeles on March 30, 2024. This event, on Chavez's birthday holiday weekend, included remarks by Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., music by the all-female mariachi group Las Colibri and remarks from Bishop Juan Carlos Mendez. Kennedy Jr. has used Cesar Chavez's name and image in his campaign for president, eliciting outrage from Chavez family members. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: RFK Jr. speaks candidly about his gravelly voice: 'If I could sound better, I would'
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: 'If I could sound better, I would,' says the presidential candidate, who has spasmodic dysphonia, a neurological condition that affects his vocal cords.
item.content:encoded: 'If I could sound better, I would,' says the presidential candidate, who has spasmodic dysphonia, a neurological condition that affects his vocal cords.

media:content.media:title: 1405450-me-0201-black-history-month-kennedy-023.jpg
media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - FEBRUARY 1, 2024 - - Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., participates in, "The Present State of Black America," panel discussion for the start of Black History Month at Artlounge Collective in Los Angeles on February 1, 2024. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Raids, fines and digging through underwear drawers: Korean president's war on 'fake news'
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.description: South Korea's president has made combating disinformation a centerpiece of his agenda. But free press advocates say his vow to keep reporters honest is a pretext to intimidate his critics
item.content:encoded: South Korea's president has made combating disinformation a centerpiece of his agenda. But free press advocates say his vow to keep reporters honest is a pretext to intimidate his critics

item.title: This epic slice of Arizona feeds their souls but lacks a basic necessity: Water
item.dc:creator: Tyrone Beason
item.description: More than a third of the Navajo Nation lacks running water. As the tribe nears a pact with Arizona over water rights, a California nonprofit looks to help.
item.content:encoded: More than a third of the Navajo Nation lacks running water. As the tribe nears a pact with Arizona over water rights, a California nonprofit looks to help.

media:content.media:title: 1384223-me-navajo-water-dig-deep-10-brv.jpg
media:content.media:description: Oljato-Monument Valley, UT - December 12: A bird takes flight over Monument Valley in the Navajo Nation on Tuesday, Dec. 12, 2023 in Oljato-Monument Valley, UT. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: These scientists think an 'awe'-some eclipse could help unite Americans in troubled times
item.dc:creator: Karen Kaplan
item.description: Awe is a serious topic among psychologists, including one at UC Irvine investigating whether awe-inspiring solar eclipses can help unite Americans.
item.content:encoded: Awe is a serious topic among psychologists, including one at UC Irvine investigating whether awe-inspiring solar eclipses can help unite Americans.

media:content.media:description: JERUSALEM, ISRAEL -- APRIL 2, 2024: Protesters holding flags, banners and lit candles march through central Jerusalem, Israel, Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Thousands of demonstrators surged through Jerusalem demanding that the government reach a cease-fire deal to free the remaining hostages held in Gaza by Hamas militants, hold early national elections and argued in favor for all draft-aged religious ultra orthodox to join the military. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)

item.title: News Analysis: Supreme Court has right and far-right wings. Their justices might not be those you'd guess

item.description: The abortion pill case shows the gap between the Supreme Court's far-right and merely conservative justices. A second Trump presidency could move the bench further right.

item.title: Los Angeles couple's Supreme Court case sheds light on immigrant visa rejections
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Luis Acensio Cordero was denied a visa to return to the U.S. from El Salvador and has been separated from his wife, Sandra Muñoz, since 2015.
item.content:encoded: Luis Acensio Cordero was denied a visa to return to the U.S. from El Salvador and has been separated from his wife, Sandra Muñoz, since 2015.

media:content.media:title: 1394064-na-pol-gang-tattoos-supreme-court-06-fo.jpg
media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA - July 13: Portrait of Sandra Munoz, a celebrated civil rights attorney in Los Angeles. She is holding a photo of her husband Luis on January 3, 2024, in Los Angeles, CA. They have been separated since 2015. Luis, who was undocumented, applied for a waiver of his illegal entry to seek citizenship after they got married. The final step was considered a formality -- he would go back to El Salvador for an interview at the U.S. consulate there and fly back to the U.S. once it was approved. Instead, it was denied. When their lawyers pressed the government for why, the State Department admitted that his tattoos -- of La Virgen de Guadalupe, a tribal design and theatrical masks -- were among the reasons they had found him to be an MS-13 gang member, an assertion he vehemently denies. Last year, the 9th Circuit sided with the couple, but the Biden administration appealed to the Supreme Court. The high court is expected to decide next month whether to take up the case, which would have ripple effects for any immigrant seeking to challenge the government's views of their character. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hay grown for cattle consumes nearly half the water drawn from Colorado River, study finds
item.dc:creator: Ian James
item.description: Much of the Colorado River's water is used for agriculture. A new study shows 46% of the water that is diverted is used to grow hay to feed cattle.
item.content:encoded: Much of the Colorado River's water is used for agriculture. A new study shows 46% of the water that is diverted is used to grow hay to feed cattle.

media:content.media:title: 835490-me-palo-verde-farm-water-deal009_LS.jpg
media:content.media:description: BLYTHE, CALIF. - SEP 7, 2021. Colorado River water irrigates a farm field in Blythe. The Metropolitan Water District is working with local growers lto leave some of their fields fallow in exchange for cash payments. The desert agricultural industry in Blythe draws water from the nearby Colorado River, and the goal is for farmers to use less river water and allow unused supplies to serve the needs of people in urban areas downstream. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Another casualty of escalating clashes in the West Bank: the Palestinian olive harvest
item.dc:creator: Nabih Bulos
item.description: As Israeli settlers use the war in Gaza as a pretext for a land grab in Palestinians' other territory, olive farmers fear their way of life may be on the verge of extinction.
item.content:encoded: As Israeli settlers use the war in Gaza as a pretext for a land grab in Palestinians' other territory, olive farmers fear their way of life may be on the verge of extinction.

media:content.media:title: 1358911-fg-0202-israelgazawar-mwy-47404.jpg
media:content.media:description: TURMUS AYYA, OCCUPIED WEST BANK -- DECEMBER 1, 2023: Amal Abu Awad, 59, harvests olives by hand on their family groves next to their home in Turmus Ayya, Occupied West Bank, Friday, Dec. 1, 2023. Since the start of the Israel-Hamas war in October, olive farmers throughout the region worry that their way of life may be on the verge of extinction N with settlers using the war as a pretext for a land grab. Abu Awad and his family have been beaten up and repeatedly threatened with expulsion from their land. Their house was vandalized, and some of their farm equipment was confiscated or destroyed. But even before the war, the annual job had become increasingly difficult over the years for the more than 100,000 Palestinian families in the West Bank that rely on it for their livelihood. (MARCUS YAM / LOS ANGELES TIMES)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times
